Dear Ms. Jenovai:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
10/3/2024. An Exit Conference occurred with the agency on 9/5/2024 Due to the
violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Rorie Dodge-Pifer 517-899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
(2) The annual reevaluation must include a determination
and assessment of all the following:
(b) Family functioning and interrelationships as
determined by observation of, and interviews with, each
member of the household and each social service worker
who has had children placed in the home during the last
licensing period.
Two of five open foster home records reviewed did not show clear documentation of
interviews/ the interview reporting by all household members.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all
the following information:
(c) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children
are interviewed, their last names may not be included in
the report.
2

Two of five open foster home records reviewed did not show clear and consistent
documentation of the interviewer, interviewee, or place of interview for all persons
interviewed.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all the following:
(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that the foster
parent has a right to have his or her written response
included as an attachment to the report required by
subrule (5) of this rule.
Two of five special evaluations reviewed did not show documentation that the
respective foster parent was informed in writing of their right to have his or her
written response attached to the report.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection August 2023, CAP approved 10/1/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services
worker that has children placed in the home.
One of five special evaluation reports reviewed did not show documentation that all
workers who had children in the foster home received a copy of the report.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim Inspection, September 2022; CAP approved 11/15/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed
corrective action plan, all social service workers who
have children placed in the home must be notified there
is a corrective action plan and what is required of the
foster parent in that plan.
One of five special evaluations reviewed did not show documentation that all
workers who had children in the foster home were advised as required by this rule.
3

CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) A comprehensive medical examination, including a
behavioral/mental health and trauma screening, within
30 calendar days from the date the child entered into an
out-of-home placement, regardless of the date of the last
physical examination.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child’s medical which was due by 10/25/2023 was completed late on
1/22/2024. The child's trauma screening which was due by 10/25/2023 was
not documented.
• A second child’s trauma screening which was due by 6/13/2024 was not
documented.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) A physical examination every 14 months.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the respective child's 14-
month’s medical exam which was due by 9/19/2023 and 5/8/2024 and was
completed late on 10/19/2023 and 7/9/2024 respectively.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(e) A dental examination must be completed within 3
months before entry into foster care or an initial dental
examination must be completed not more than 90
calendar days after entry into a foster care out-of-home
placement. A child entering foster care under 1 year of
4

age must have an initial dental exam within 3 months of
his or her first birthday.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child's initial dental
exam was due by 12/28/2023 and was completed late on 2/5/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404(4).
In one of eight open foster child records reviewed the record showed the child's
Initial Service Plan (ISP) did not show documentation of (c) as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim inspection, September 2022; CAP approved 11/15/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), must include all the following
information:
(g) A child behavior support plan that includes any
changes made since the previous plan and is to be used
by the foster parents.
In one of eight open foster child records reviewed, the record showed two Updated
Service Plans (USP) which did not show documentation of a specific behavior
support plan to be used for the child.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection, August 2023; CAP approved 10/1/2023.
Interim Inspection, September 2022; CAP approved 11/15/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact.
(4) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between
siblings who are not placed together except when there
5

is a court determination that contact is detrimental to
either child.
In one of eight open foster child records reviewed where siblings were split, the
record did not show documentation of a November and December 2023 sibling visit.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection, August 2023; CAP approved 10/1/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12604 Orientation.
(2) The orientation must include a review of all the
following:
(a) Program statement, policies, and procedures.
In two of three adoptive family records reviewed the record did not show
documentation that the family was provided an orientation which included providing
the family with a copy of the of the program statement and policies and procedures.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim Inspection, September 2022; CAP approved 11/15/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
Three of three adoptive family records reviewed showed the family’s adoptive family
evaluation was not completed within 90 days of the respective family's 2/8/2023,
8/16/2023 and 10/17/2023 application date, as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption
with a signed and dated copy of the evaluation and
recommendation upon its completion.
In one of three adoptive family records reviewed the record showed the family's
adoptive family evaluations completed on 6/12/2024 and 6/21/2024 were not
provided to the family timely upon their completion.
6

Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection, August 2023: CAP approved 10/1/2023.
Interim Inspection, September 2022, CAP approved 11/15/2022.
ADM 300 Child Adoption Assessment.
Prior to completing the child adoption assessment, the
adoption worker must make a minimum of two face-to-
face contacts with the child, with at least one in the
home, and one face-to-face with the child's current
caregiver, even if the caregiver(s) are not interested in
adopting the child. The contacts must be documented in
the child assessment.
In two of three open adoption records reviewed, the child's adoption assessment did
not show two face-to face contacts with the child as required by the rule.
FOM 722-6-B Family Team Meeting.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using
the FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must
be completed for each type of meeting.
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the
required time frames as out lined in the following table:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date. Note: This FTM may be
combined with the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date. Permanent Ward Service
Plan (PWSP) – within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child’s record did not show documentation of an FTM for the child’s
9/29/2023-10/23/2023 ISP. One was completed after the period on
10/27/2023.
• A second child's record did not show documentation of an FTM for the child's
2/6/2024-4/29/2024 USP.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection, August 2023, CAP approved 10/1/2023.
Interim Inspection, September 2022, CAP approved 11/15/2022.
7

FOM 722- 8D Treatment Plan.
Agreement and signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
Parents who are a member of a participating household.
Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages.
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
Seven of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child’s 9/29/2023-10/23/2023 treatment plan was not signed by the birth
parents or caregiver. This child’s 10/24/2023-1/5/2024 and the 1/6/2024-
3/21/2024 treatment plan was not signed by the birth parents; and that latter
treatment plan was not signed by the caregiver. Additionally, the child’s
3/22/2024-6/11/2024 treatment plan was not signed by the birth mother.
• A second child’s 9/25/2023-10/24/2023 treatment plan was not signed by the
birth father, and it was signed late by the foster parent on 9/4/2024.
Additionally, the child’s 1/17/2024-4/15/2024 and 4/16/2024-7/11/2024
treatment plan was not signed by the birth father. The 1/17/2024-4/15/2024
treatment plan was signed late by the foster parent on 6/12/2024.
• A third child’s 4/22/2023-7/10/2023 treatment plan was not signed by the
caregiver and was not provided to the birth father until 10/4/2023.
• A fourth child’s 8/29/2023-9/19/2023 treatment plan was not signed by the
birth father until 11/8/2023. This child’s respective 9/20/2023-12/4/2023,
12/5/2023-2/20/2024 and 2/21/2024-5/10/2024 treatment plan was not signed
by the caregiver until 7/25/2024. The birth father did not sign the 9/20/2023-
12/5/4/2023 and 12/5/2023-2/20/2024 treatment plan.
• A fifth child’s 6/26/2023-9/21/2023 treatment plan was not signed by the
caregiver, and the caregiver did not sign the child’s 2/14/2024-5/13/2024
treatment plan until 7/24/2024.
• A sixth child’s 5/8/2024-6/5/2024 treatment plan was not signed by the
caregiver, and it was not signed by the birth mother until 9/3/2024.
• A seventh child’s 11/8/2023-2/5/2024 treatment was not signed by the foster
parent; and the 2/6/2024-4/29/2024 treatment plan was not signed by the
foster parent until 7/19/2024.
8

Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection, August 2023; CAP approved 10/1/2023.
Interim Inspection, September 2022: CAP approved 11/15/2022.
FOM 801-3 Medical Passport.
Updated Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
Note: Medical information is to be entered within five-
business days of receipt of the health information.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show compliance:
• Two records did not show documentation of a June 2024 medical passport
that was due for the respective child.
• A third and fourth record did not show documentation of an August 2024
medical passport that was due for the respective child.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal Inspection, August 2023; CAP approved 10/1/2023.
Interim Inspection, September 2022; CAP approved 11/15/2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
ACT 116 -722.120(3)
• The agency was provided technical assistance on how not to utilize child
protective services and maltreatment in care language in special evaluation
reports, even when stated by the foster parent or in intake information.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
FOM 722.6B Family team meeting
• The agency was advised that showing clear and consistent documentation of the
date of the FTM on the DHS-1105 form and ensuring that this form lists the
names of the participates on it, may aid it in showing ongoing compliance to the
rule.
9

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period. This CAP related to the agency’s 2023 Renewal inspection
completed on 8/23/2023 where the CAP was approved on 10/1/2023. The agency
received 17 violations, 8 of which are repeat violations this year. The agency’s
compliance around these 8 rule violations is as follows: with the exception of
R400.327(5)(c) and FOM 722-8D where the number of individual cases cited
increased from 1 of 3 to 2 of 5; and 2 of 8 to 7 of 8; the other 6 repeat violations
with respect to the number of individual cases cited either decreased or stayed the
same.
As it relates to the agency’s efforts to achieve CAP, the agency provided
documentation showing:
• It updated its job description related to its administrative clerk’s position so
as to reflect the education requirement for this position.
• It revised its quarterly home visit tools used for foster home visits; and its
licensing checklist used for licensing reports. Additionality, the agency
showed, or I saw via the file reviews, examples of documentation of those
forms usage, and of spreadsheet tracking.
• Examples of quarterly tracking and discussions of the reported topics at
supervisor/worker supervision meetings, via meeting agendas and
supervision notes.
• Proofs of foster care training, licensing, foster care and adoption meetings
discussions, and team meetings of topic indicated in the CAP; and binders
containing reported information.
• Examples of emails to foster care staff related to child immunizations.
• Example of reminder emails sent to supervisors and workers related to
report time frames, their Book of Business and outlook Calanders.
• Examples of licensing, foster care and adoption supervisor supervision
notes showing review of discussion of special evaluation’s, inspection
reports, family team meetings, service plans, monthly visits, sibling visits,
medical/dental, medical passport, adoption evaluation due dates and
submission of these evaluations to families.
• Various proofs of the CAP implementation or completion was also verified
by way of what was seen or assessed through my case file reviews. This
related to such items as performance evaluations; home visits, updated
service plans; child adoption assessment time frames, and adoption
10

quarterly progress reports, of which the agency had no late or missing
reports or visits.
The agency’s efforts to complete this CAP resulted in some progress in various
areas. The agency was not totally successful with all, as indicated by the repeat
violations indicated in this report. The agency reports it continues its efforts in all
areas. It is also worth noting, the agency has updated its policies and procedures
to be more aligned and reflective of the rules.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator (CA) report dated 8/19/2024. The CA’s
report indicated areas of repeat noncompliance was impacted by a workforce
crisis/ worker turnover. The CA reported due to the worker crisis, supervisors
spent much time completing tasks the worker should have been completing. The
CA further reported it is systemic to foster care that foster care workers and
supervisors have a higher expectation on them and have higher workloads than
other positions in child welfare. This fact, and their expected responsibility to
maintain child safety weighs on the positions and impacts worker stability/turnover.
The agency also reported concern that the department places different standards
on agencies as it relates to compliance, and that such differences is a challenge
that impacts compliance.
The CA reported the CAP has assisted both workers and supervisors in knowing
expectations and that its CAP has been reviewed with staff monthly at meetings.
The CA reported that as with new changes, sometimes in an effort to correct and
improve in one area, one might lose oversight in others. Notwithstanding that
challenge, the CA reported the agency has increased its compliance in many of
the requirements related to KPIs (Key Performance Indicators). The CA reported
the agency will continue to monitor the agency’s compliance on the CAP through
supervision and team meetings.
Financial Overview
The agency submitted a copy of it 2024 annual budget and a copy of it 9/30/2023
independent financial audit. A review of this information did not show concerns.
Staff and Youth Interviews
In addition to a discussion with the licensee designee, the program manager and
two of the agency's supervisors, I interviewed, one licensing worker, one adoption
worker, and one foster care worker. The area of strengths reported by these
workers related to there being work flexibility, good agency communication,
supervisory support, and a connection to management, in that no administrative
staff behaves as if they are more important than another person. Areas of growth
needed related to having supervisors go out more on visits with new workers,
managerial staff advising staff of their management style upfront, management
conducting more work with staff upfront on how all things/tasks connect to each
person’s position and the agency and its responsibilities, and continued
recognition by management of the nature and difficulty of the job, and the stress
the responsibilities of the job can have on workers.
11

Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the agency's site did not reveal any concerns. The agency has
sufficient space and equipment for its staff, and case files are securely stored.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There was one safety alert pertaining to an unlicensed relative home:
Concern:
The unlicensed relative home did not have an operable smoke detector in the home.
Resolution:
The agency provided the unlicensed relative with an operable smoke detector on
7/2/2024 and it was installed on 7/2/2024. The agency provided a photo showing
the installed device.
Concern:
One of the unlicensed relative’s bedrooms could not be viewed due to the relative’s
son sleeping in the room during the Division of Child Welfare Licensing Analyst’s
home visit. Safety concerns could not be assessed.
Resolution:
The agency reported the bedroom in question was viewed by the agency worker on
7/2/2024, and there were no safety concerns. The agency provided photos of the
room.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
